Government Ministers have been accused of putting the North East’s car industry at risk by continuing to argue about Brexit.
Cabinet divisions are being aired openly, with Business Secretary Greg Clark on one side and Boris Johnson, the Foreign Secretary, on the other.
Mr Clark backs Prime Minister Theresa May’s plan for a ‘Customs Partnership’ to replace the existing Customs Union arrangement the UK is part of.
He said the plan was needed to protect manufacturers.
But Mr Johnson has called the proposal “crazy”, and appears to have the backing of many Cabinet colleagues.
Sedgefield MP Phil Wilson, whose constituency includes the Hitachi train building facility in Newton Aycliffe, said the continued uncertainty was discouraging investment in the region. Sedgefield MP Phil Wilson at the Hitachi opening ceremony (Image: Unknown)
He said: “The Customs Union is vitally important. A lot of manufacturers depend on the ability to import parts into the Uk without delays.
“The car industry has made it clear how important this is. They’re not just saying that for the sake of it.
“The Cabinet is divided between people peddling a fiction and those setting out facts.”
Mrs May’s Customs Partnership plan is an attempt to answer the question of what to do about the Customs Union.
This is the mechanism that allows products to be transported without restrictions between EU countries.
Instead of checking goods at the borders of each individual country, they are checked at the borders of the Customs Union as a whole. The EU and Union flags (Image: PA)
So once they are inside the EU - or if they were manufactured in the EU in the first place - then no more checks are needed.
The Customs Union matters a lot to the automotive sector, and to some other major manufacturers with lengthy and complex supply chains. Read More Japanese firms like Nissan 'won't invest in the North East due to Brexit uncertainty'
They don’t manufacture every component themselves, but instead employ suppliers across the EU to make parts for them.
However, continued membership of the existing EU Customs Union would prevent the UK from signing its own trade deals. Read More
